newsitem.title: USA: U.S. cash soymeal - Rail basis off as demand slips.
newsitem.headline: U.S. cash soymeal - Rail basis off as demand slips.

text.p: Railcar offers for high- protein soymeal weakened in the Midwest on Monday as demand slipped in anticipation of lower prices later this week.

Processors and brokers quoted many locations $1 per ton lower in nominal dealings, with the $3 break in futures Monday and last week's pickup in the weekly crush lending psychological support to a waiting game by buyers. Futures are still up $60 a ton this year even after falling $20 in the last two weeks, cash dealers noted.
"Demand has really backed off," said one rail broker. "But I suspect even though brief downtimes will continue, a lot of plants will shove maintenance back to summer to keep crushing."

Last week's National Oilseed Processors Association crush of 26.2 million bushels came in higher than the previous week's 25.9 million, which was less than expected. That fall-off was said to be caused in part by unexpected downtimes at Southeast plants.
A large crusher at Kansas City bucked the trend on Monday and quoted meal $2 higher, with local tightness cited.
